page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF MID DEVON
page.content: The climate is warm and damp due to the prevailing west wind. The area is mostly 600 to 700 feet above sea level and exposed to the wind, but suffers little from frost and snow. The soil is not rich therefore the area lends itself more to animal husbandry than arable farming. The underlying soil is clay making drainage a problem for most of the year and many acres have to be drained before they are viable. Undulating ground makes tractor work hazardous and sometimes even impossible. There are areas of woodland both coniferous and deciduous. Some trees have been felled to create more valuable grassland, but some landowners have planted many hardwood trees resulting in a noticeable increase in bird types and numbers.
